sn22.145:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, anattā; tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn22.145:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire and greed for what is not-self. …”

sn22.145:1.4.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā; tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn22.145:1.8.pli: viññāṇaṃ anattā; tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn22.145:1.9.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, anattā; tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn22.146:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith, this is what’s in line with the teaching.

sn22.146:1.3.pli: yaṃ rūpe nibbidābahulo vihareyya. Vedanāya …pe… saññāya … saṅkhāresu … viññāṇe nibbidābahulo vihareyya.
sn22.146:1.3.eng: They should live full of disillusionment for form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.146:1.4.pli: Yo rūpe nibbidābahulo viharanto, vedanāya … saññāya … saṅkhāresu … viññāṇe nibbidābahulo viharanto rūpaṃ parijānāti, vedanaṃ … saññaṃ … saṅkhāre … viññāṇaṃ parijānāti;
sn22.146:1.4.eng: Living in this way, they completely understand form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.146:1.5.pli: so rūpaṃ parijānaṃ vedanaṃ parijānaṃ saññaṃ parijānaṃ saṅkhāre parijānaṃ viññāṇaṃ parijānaṃ parimuccati rūpamhā, parimuccati vedanāya, parimuccati saññāya, parimuccati saṅkhārehi, parimuccati viññāṇamhā, parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi; ‘parimuccati dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn22.146:1.5.eng: Completely understanding form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness, they’re freed from these things. They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They’re freed from suffering, I say.”

sn22.147:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith, this is what’s in line with the teaching.

sn22.147:1.3.eng: They should meditate observing impermanence in form,

sn22.147:1.8.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.”

sn22.148:1.1.comm: This corresponds to SN 22.41. | The PTS edition omitted the text of this discourse, apparently by oversight. This means that the numbers of the subsequent discourses in this Saṁyutta are short by one.

sn22.148:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith, this is what’s in line with the teaching.

sn22.148:1.3.eng: They should meditate observing suffering in form,

sn22.148:1.8.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.”

sn22.149:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith, this is what’s in line with the teaching.

sn22.149:1.3.eng: They should meditate observing not-self in form,

sn22.149:1.11.pli: viññāṇe anattānupassī viharanto rūpaṃ parijānāti, vedanaṃ …pe…

sn22.149:1.15.pli: So rūpaṃ parijānaṃ vedanaṃ parijānaṃ saññaṃ parijānaṃ saṅkhāre parijānaṃ viññāṇaṃ parijānaṃ parimuccati rūpamhā, parimuccati vedanāya, parimuccati saññāya, parimuccati saṅkhārehi, parimuccati viññāṇamhā, parimuccati jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi;

sn22.149:1.16.eng: They’re freed from suffering, I say.”

sn22.15:1.5.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.15:1.5.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.15:1.5.comm: See note on this phrase at SN 22.15:1.5.

sn22.15:1.9.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.

sn22.15:1.15.pli: yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn22.15:1.15.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.15:1.17.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.150:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhan”ti?
sn22.150:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn22.150:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.150:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati rūpaṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
sn22.150:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.

sn22.150:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati viññāṇaṃ upādāya uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
sn22.150:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.

sn22.150:1.12.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.150:1.12.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.150:1.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhan”ti?
sn22.150:1.14.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn22.150:1.21.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.150:1.21.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.150:1.23.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyya ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhan”ti?
sn22.150:1.23.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”

sn22.150:1.26.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.151:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa:
sn22.151:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what,
sn22.151:1.2.comm: Kiṁ upādāya might be rendered as “derived from what”, but the fact that it is parallel with abhinivissa (“insist”) shows that the sense “grasping” is prominent. Grasping is the “taking up” of the view of self, which hardens into “insistence”.

sn22.151:1.3.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassatī”ti?
sn22.151:1.3.eng: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.151:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.151:1.5.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa …pe…
sn22.151:1.5.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form …
sn22.151:1.5.comm: This is another context that emphasizes the “existence” of the aggregates (see SN 22.94:1.5 and note).

sn22.151:1.6.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa:
sn22.151:1.6.eng: When consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness,

sn22.151:1.7.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati.
sn22.151:1.7.eng: someone regards it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’

sn22.151:1.11.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attāti samanupasseyyāti?
sn22.151:1.11.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.151:1.18.pli: vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attāti samanupasseyyāti?
sn22.151:1.18.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would you regard it like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.151:1.21.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.152:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.152:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn22.152:1.3.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’”ti?
sn22.152:1.3.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”

sn22.152:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.152:1.5.pli: “Rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.152:1.5.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn22.152:1.6.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn22.152:1.6.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn22.152:1.10.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.152:1.10.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn22.152:1.11.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’ti.
sn22.152:1.11.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.’

sn22.152:2.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.152:2.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.152:2.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn22.152:2.6.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn22.152:2.7.pli: ‘so attā, so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’”ti?
sn22.152:2.7.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”

sn22.152:2.14.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.152:2.14.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.152:2.16.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn22.152:2.16.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn22.152:2.17.pli: ‘so attā so loko, so pecca bhavissāmi nicco dhuvo sassato avipariṇāmadhammo’”ti?
sn22.152:2.17.eng: ‘The self and the cosmos are one and the same. After death I will be that, permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable’?”

sn22.152:2.20.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.153:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.153:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:

sn22.153:1.3.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?
sn22.153:1.3.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”

sn22.153:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.153:1.5.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.153:1.5.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:

sn22.153:1.6.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.153:1.6.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn22.153:1.10.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa, evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjati:
sn22.153:1.10.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:

sn22.153:1.11.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.153:1.11.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’

sn22.153:1.15.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.153:1.15.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.153:1.17.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn22.153:1.17.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn22.153:1.18.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?
sn22.153:1.18.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”

sn22.153:1.25.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.153:1.25.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.153:1.27.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi uppajjeyya:
sn22.153:1.27.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:

sn22.153:1.28.pli: ‘no cassaṃ, no ca me siyā, nābhavissa, na me bhavissatī’”ti?
sn22.153:1.28.eng: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”

sn22.153:1.31.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.154:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa micchādiṭṭhi uppajjatī”ti?
sn22.154:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does wrong view arise?”

sn22.154:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.154:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa micchādiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.154:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, wrong view arises.

sn22.154:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa micchādiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.154:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, wrong view arises.

sn22.154:1.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya micchādiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.154:1.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would wrong view arise?”

sn22.154:1.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.154:1.20.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.154:1.22.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, api nu taṃ anupādāya micchādiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.154:1.22.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would wrong view arise?”

sn22.154:1.25.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.155:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa sakkāyadiṭṭhi uppajjatī”ti?
sn22.155:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does substantialist view arise?”

sn22.155:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.155:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa sakkāyadiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.155:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, substantialist view arises.

sn22.155:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa sakkāyadiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.155:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, substantialist view arises.

sn22.155:1.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya sakkāyadiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.155:1.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would substantialist view arise?”

sn22.155:1.21.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya sakkāyadiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.155:1.21.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would substantialist view arise?”

sn22.155:1.24.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.156:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa attānudiṭṭhi uppajjatī”ti?
sn22.156:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does theory of self arise?”
sn22.156:1.2.comm: “Theory of self” (attānudiṭṭhi) is not a defined technical term. Anudiṭḥi is used for developed “theories” (eg. DN 1 throughout), and this holds true for “theory of self” (DN 15:24.12), especially the Upaniṣadic view (Snp 5.16:4.3).

sn22.156:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.156:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa attānudiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.156:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, theory of self arises.

sn22.156:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa attānudiṭṭhi uppajjati.
sn22.156:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, theory of self arises.

sn22.156:1.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya attānudiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.156:1.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would theory of self arise?”

sn22.156:1.21.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya attānudiṭṭhi uppajjeyyā”ti?
sn22.156:1.21.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would theory of self arise?”

sn22.156:1.24.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.157:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhā”ti?
sn22.157:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do fetters, insistence, and shackles arise?”

sn22.157:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.157:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhā.
sn22.157:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, fetters, insistence, and shackles arise.

sn22.157:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhā.
sn22.157:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, fetters, insistence, and shackles arise.

sn22.157:1.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyyuṃ saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhā”ti?
sn22.157:1.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would fetters, insistence, and shackles arise?”

sn22.157:1.16.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.158:1.2.pli: “Kismiṃ nu kho, bhikkhave, sati, kiṃ upādāya, kiṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhājjhosānā”ti?
sn22.158:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do fetters, insistence, shackles, and attachments arise?”

sn22.158:1.3.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”

sn22.158:1.4.pli: “rūpe kho, bhikkhave, sati, rūpaṃ upādāya, rūpaṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhājjhosānā.
sn22.158:1.4.eng: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, fetters, insistence, shackles, and attachments arise.

sn22.158:1.8.pli: viññāṇe sati, viññāṇaṃ upādāya, viññāṇaṃ abhinivissa uppajjanti saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhājjhosānā.
sn22.158:1.8.eng: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, fetters, insistence, shackles, and attachments arise.

sn22.158:1.13.pli: api nu taṃ anupādāya uppajjeyyuṃ saṃyojanābhinivesavinibandhājjhosānā”ti?
sn22.158:1.13.eng: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would fetters, insistence, shackles, and attachments arise?”

sn22.158:1.16.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”
